History: History: The settlement was originally established in 1957 as part of Mingochi village. Later due to the vastness of the area, Mr. Andrew Kalunga Chowa asked chief Chamuka and village headman Mingochi to make the swampy area his village. He was granted permission to set up a new village in 1998 and the settlement became known as Shipunga.
Priorities: Waterdrainage, Sanitationsewage, Tenuresecurity, Housing, Electricity, Waterdrainage, Sanitationsewage, Tenuresecurity, Housing, Electricity

History: History: The settlement began as a political site office for UNIP during the struggle for independence. Later on in 1970 the government resettled in the area people who were moved from Kabwe to pave way for construction of various infrastructure. The settlement was run under a political administration until 1984 when customary administration took over.

History:
History: The inhabitants of what is now called Ngala Village migrated from the Luano Valley of Central Province back in 1977 under the leadership of Nelson Ngala who also doubled as Court Messenger at Chief Chamuka's palace(Late Chamuka).
He was enthroned as Village headman Ngala in1977 and continued to serve his people for the next 23 years until the year 2000 when he handed the reigns to his nephew Bornface Ngala.
Bornface,who is the current headman Ngala,has been ruling this village for the past 20 years.
Priorities: Electricity, Sanitationsewage, Other, Other, Other, Electricity, Sanitationsewage, Other, Other, Other

History: History: The settlement was started by a witch doctor named Mponge who had migrated from Mkushi in 1940. Some people who went to seek his services ended up staying there permanently and later other newcomers came along from other nearby areas. Previously the area was grazing land for livestock because of its marshy environment.
Priorities: Tenuresecurity, Sanitationsewage, Waterdrainage, Electricity, Housing, Tenuresecurity, Sanitationsewage, Waterdrainage, Electricity, Housing

History: History: The settlement was established by Mr. Kaputula in 1940 after he migrated from chief Kanyesha's area in Mkushi district. He was allowed to settle in the area by chief Chamuka who considered him a relative as they were from the same clan (the goat clan). He was given the name Kaputula because of his love for wearing shorts.
Priorities: Tenuresecurity, Waterdrainage, Sanitationsewage, Housing, Electricity, Tenuresecurity, Waterdrainage, Sanitationsewage, Housing, Electricity

History:
History: Lupaka Settlement was established in 1906 under the headmanship of Lupaka,who together with his elder brother Mwanawasa,migrated to this place in the company of Chief Mukuni N'gombe.Mwanawasa never became the headman, instead the young Lupaka became the first headman who was then succeeded by headman Chakalashi.
The people here moved to the present day Mukobola village and Chakalashi died here.He was succeeded by Poster Kayanda Mwanawasa who later died in 1985.The young brother by the name of Dickson Mwanawasa who only lasted for one year and died in 1986.The village remained without a headman for two years and in 1988,James Likwabila succeeded his uncle Dickson.Likwabila ruled the village from 1988 to 2012.Once again,the settlement was deprived of the headman until 2019 when Edith Likwabila took over the reigns and until now she is the current headperson of Lupaka village.
Priorities: Waterdrainage, Tenuresecurity, Other, Other, Other, Waterdrainage, Tenuresecurity, Other, Other, Other

Mr. Musumali later invited his friends and family from nearby slums in Kabwe and the settlement. By 1970 the settlement had expanded as more people who came to look for work in Kabwe settled there.

The area did not have water, it was through the government that they brought up the water initiative. The people in the area saw that it was a nice thing that they named the area as Chawama meaning nice thing.

He was allowed to settle at present day Ndililwa which he called by the said name which means 'one you can cry on'.

The name of the settlement came about as a result of the underwear that was hanged on a tree after the woman was violated (raped). When she reported the case to the police, the police started calling the place Chinika (underwear).

History: History: George settlement was established as early as the 1950s. This land was farmland owned by three white men; George, Feligan and Scott. Soon after independence (1964), George left the farm and as a result the farm workers and other people began to migrate to the area establishing their own settlement. In 1977 George was legalized which helped to decongest the area.

History: History: The area was bare land that was discovered by Chief Kapijipanga. He had come across the Solwezi monument as he was seeing the extent of his land. Due to the beauty of the Solwezi monument he named this area Kyalalakuba. The first people given permission by the Chief to settle in the area was a lady by the name of Mpandwe who was seeking land so that she could settle. Other people later followed her and settled in the area.

History: History: The settlement was a village for the Soli people. The settlement started due to the people working in the farms. Lilanda got its name from Chief Lilanda who used to stay in that area. When the Chief left the area, government came in in 1965-1968 and built houses. People kept moving to the area in search of employment such as working on farms.
